elements.Name: Hydrogen
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by Henry Cavendish in 1766, hydrogen was prepared by reacting metal with acid. The name comes from the Greek words hydro (water) and genes (forming). Antoine Lavoisier named the element based on its ability to form water.

Physical Properties:

Hydrogen is a colorless, odorless, and tasteless gas at room temperature. It is highly flammable and exists as a diatomic molecule (H₂) under standard conditions. It is also the most abundant element in the universe.

Chemical Properties:

  • Reacts with oxygen to form water (H₂O).
  • Acts as both a reducing and an oxidizing agent.
  • Forms hydrides with many elements.
  • Used in the production of ammonia (NH₃).
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 1
Number of shells: 1
Electronic configuration: 1s¹.

elements.Name: Helium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

First observed by Jules Janssen in 1868 as a bright yellow line in the solar spectrum during a solar eclipse. The name derives from the Greek word helios (sun), as it was discovered in the sun’s spectrum. Joseph Norman Lockyer and Edward Frankland named helium.

Physical Properties:

Helium is a colorless, odorless, and tasteless gas. It has the lowest boiling point of all elements and is the second most abundant element in the universe. It is extremely light and inert.

Chemical Properties:

  • Does not form chemical compounds under normal conditions.
  • Extremely stable due to its complete outer electron shell.
  • Used in cryogenics and as a shielding gas.
  • Essential for MRI machines and scientific research.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 2
Number of shells: 1
Electronic configuration: 1s².

elements.Name: Lithium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by Johann Arfvedson in 1817 while analyzing petalite ore. The name originates from the Greek word lithos (stone), reflecting its discovery in rock material. Johan August Arfvedson named it lithium.

Physical Properties:

Lithium is a soft, silvery-white metal with the lowest density of all solid elements at room temperature. It has a melting point of 180.54°C and is highly reactive with water.

Chemical Properties:

  • Readily forms lithium ions (Li⁺).
  • Reacts vigorously with water to form lithium hydroxide (LiOH) and hydrogen gas.
  • Used in rechargeable batteries, such as lithium-ion batteries.
  • Important in psychiatric medications due to its use in certain pharmaceuticals for treating conditions like bipolar disorder.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 3
Number of shells: 2
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s¹.

elements.Name: Beryllium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Independently isolated by Friedrich Wöhler and Antoine Bussy in 1828, beryllium was named after beryl, the mineral in which it was discovered. French chemist Nicholas-Louis Vauquelin named it.

Physical Properties:

Beryllium is a steel-gray metal that is strong, lightweight, and has a high melting point of 1287°C. It remains solid at room temperature and is notable for being one of the lightest metals with this property. Additionally, beryllium is transparent to X-rays.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms strong covalent bonds due to its small atomic size.
  • Resistant to oxidation at room temperature due to a protective oxide layer.
  • Used extensively in aerospace alloys because of its strength-to-weight ratio and thermal stability.
  • Toxic if inhaled as dust or fumes; handling requires proper safety precautions.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 4
Number of shells: 2
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s².

elements.Name: Boron
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1808 by Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac and Louis Jacques Thénard, who produced impure boron. The name comes from the Arabic buraq and Persian burah, referring to borax. Sir Humphry Davy named the element boron in 1808.

Physical Properties:

Boron can appear as a black-brown amorphous solid or red crystals. It has a high melting point of approximately 2076°C, is hard and wear-resistant, but acts as a poor conductor of electricity at room temperature[7].

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms strong covalent bonds due to its small atomic size.
  • Used in various applications such as fiber optics and ceramics due to its hardness.
  • An essential micronutrient for plant growth, playing roles in cell wall formation and carbohydrate metabolism[2].
  • Forms many complex hydrides with other elements.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 5
Number of shells: 2
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p¹.

elements.Name: Carbon
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Known to prehistoric humans in the form of charcoal and diamonds. The name carbon comes from the Latin carbo, meaning “charcoal,” and was given by French chemist Antoine Lavoisier in 1789.

Physical Properties:

Carbon exists in multiple allotropes, including diamond and graphite. Diamond is extremely hard and acts as an electrical insulator, while graphite is soft and an excellent conductor of electricity. Graphite has a high melting point of approximately 3550°C under standard conditions.

Chemical Properties:

  • Serves as the basis for organic chemistry due to its ability to form long chains and complex rings.
  • An essential element for all known life forms on Earth.
  • Able to form millions of different compounds with other elements due to its versatility in bonding arrangements.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 6
Number of shells: 2
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p².

elements.Name: Nitrogen
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by Daniel Rutherford in 1772 as a distinct component of air; named nitrogen by Jean-Antoine-Claude Chaptal in 1790 from the Greek nitron and genes, meaning nitre forming.

Physical Properties:

Nitrogen is a colorless, odorless, tasteless gas that exists primarily as a diatomic molecule (N₂). It makes up approximately 78% of Earth's atmosphere and has a low boiling point of -195.8°C.

Chemical Properties:

  • The nitrogen molecule forms strong triple covalent bonds between its atoms.
  • An essential component for amino acids and proteins due to its role in biological systems.
  • Used extensively in fertilizers because it is crucial for plant growth.
  • Critical for various biological processes including metabolism and DNA synthesis.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 7
Number of shells: 2
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p³.

elements.Name: Oxygen
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by Joseph Priestley in 1774 by heating mercury(II) oxide; named oxygen by Antoine Lavoisier in 1777 from the Greek oxys and genes, meaning acid forming.

Physical Properties:

Oxygen is a colorless, odorless, tasteless gas that exists primarily as a diatomic molecule (O₂). It is essential for respiration and makes up approximately 21% of Earth's atmosphere.

Chemical Properties:

  • Serves as a strong oxidizing agent.
  • Supports combustion reactions by providing oxygen necessary for burning.
  • Critical for cellular respiration processes within living organisms.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 8
Number of shells: 2
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁴.

elements.Name: Fluorine
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by Henri Moissan in 1886 through electrolysis; named fluorine by André Ampère in 1812 from the Latin fluere, meaning to flow.

Physical Properties:

Fluorine is a pale yellow gas at room temperature and pressure. It is known as the most reactive non-metal due to its high reactivity with other elements. Fluorine is highly toxic and possesses the highest electron affinity among all elements.

Chemical Properties:

  • The most electronegative element, capable of forming strong bonds with most other elements.
  • Used extensively in fluoride compounds for various applications, including dental health products like toothpaste.
  • An important component in the pharmaceutical industry due to its ability to enhance drug properties and stability.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 9
Number of shells: 2
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁵.

elements.Name: Neon
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by William Ramsay and Morris Travers in 1898 in liquid air; named neon the same year from the Greek neos, meaning new.

Physical Properties:

Neon is a colorless and odorless gas at room temperature but emits an orange-red glow when excited electrically. It has a very low boiling point of -246.08°C and is known for being one of the lightest noble gases after helium.

Chemical Properties:

  • A chemically inert element due to its full outer energy level, which makes it non-reactive under normal conditions.
  • Does not naturally form compounds with other elements because of its stable electronic configuration.
  • Widely used in neon signs due to its bright orange-red color when electrically excited.
  • Playing an important role in laser technology, particularly in gas lasers where neon can be combined with other gases like helium for specific applications.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 10
Number of shells: 2
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶.

elements.Name: Sodium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by Humphry Davy in 1807 through electrolysis; named sodium by Davy the same year from the Latin natrium, derived from Egyptian natron and related to the English word soda.

Physical Properties:

Sodium is a soft, silvery-white metal that reacts highly with water. It has a low melting point of 97.72°C and serves as an excellent conductor of electricity due to its free electrons.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms strong ionic bonds due to its tendency to readily lose one electron, creating positively charged ions (Na⁺).
  • An essential component for nerve function in biological systems, helping transmit signals across neurons.
  • A key ingredient in common table salt (sodium chloride, NaCl), which is crucial for maintaining proper fluid balance and blood pressure in humans.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 11
Number of shells: 3
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s¹.

elements.Name: Magnesium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Recognized as an element by Joseph Black in 1755; named magnesium from Magnesia, a district in Eastern Thessaly, Greece.

Physical Properties:

Magnesium is a silvery-white metal that is both lightweight and strong. It has a high melting point of approximately 650°C and serves as a good conductor of heat.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms strong ionic bonds due to its ability to readily lose electrons.
  • An essential component for chlorophyll production in plants, playing a crucial role in photosynthesis.
  • Used extensively in the creation of lightweight alloys due to its strength-to-weight ratio.
  • Critical for various biological processes within living organisms, including muscle function and nerve transmission.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 12
Number of shells: 3
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s².

elements.Name: Aluminum
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by Hans Christian Ørsted in 1825, who first isolated the metal; named aluminum from the Latin alumen, meaning alum.

Physical Properties:

Aluminum is a silvery-white metal with low density, approximately one-third that of steel or copper. It is an excellent conductor of both heat and electricity and forms a protective oxide layer when exposed to air, which enhances its corrosion resistance.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms strong bonds with oxygen, leading to the formation of aluminum oxide (Al₂O₃), which protects it from further corrosion.
  • Resistant to corrosion due to this protective oxide layer that forms naturally on its surface.
  • Widely used in packaging (e.g., foil and cans) and construction materials due to its lightweight nature and durability.
  • It is the third most abundant element in Earth's crust.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 13
Number of shells: 3
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p¹.

elements.Name: Silicon
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by Jöns Jacob Berzelius in 1824, who produced pure silicon; named silicon by Scottish chemist Thomas Thomson in 1831 from the Latin silex, meaning flint or hard stone.

Physical Properties:

Silicon is a dark gray metalloid with a bluish tinge and exhibits semiconductor properties. It has a high melting point of approximately 1414°C and is the second most abundant element in Earth's crust[5][6].

Chemical Properties:

  • Silicon forms tetrahedral structures due to its ability to bond with four other atoms, typically oxygen or carbon.
  • An essential component in the semiconductor industry for manufacturing electronic devices like transistors and microchips.
  • Naturally forms silicates, which are compounds found extensively in minerals such as quartz and mica.
  • Critical for solar cells due to its ability to convert sunlight into electrical energy efficiently.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 14
Number of shells: 3
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p².

elements.Name: Phosphorus
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by Hennig Brand in 1669 while searching for the philosopher's stone; named phosphorus by Brand the same year from the Greek phosphoros, meaning light-bearing.

Physical Properties:

Phosphorus exists in multiple allotropes, including white, red, and black forms. White phosphorus is particularly notable for its ability to glow in the dark and is highly reactive with air. Phosphorus is essential for life as it plays critical roles in biological systems.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms strong covalent bonds with other elements.
  • A key component of DNA and RNA molecules due to its role as a backbone structure.
  • Widely used in fertilizers because of its importance for plant growth.
  • Playing an important role in energy transfer within cells through ATP (adenosine triphosphate) molecules.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 15
Number of shells: 3
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p³.

elements.Name: Sulfur
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Known to prehistoric humans; named sulfur from the Latin sulphur, meaning sulfur.

Physical Properties:

Sulfur is a yellow crystalline solid that exists in multiple allotropes. It has a relatively low melting point of 115.21°C and is known for its distinctive odor, often compared to the smell of rotten eggs due to hydrogen sulfide gas (H₂S) emissions when it reacts with moisture.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms strong covalent bonds with other elements, particularly in sulfur-sulfur bonds within its allotropes.
  • An essential component for proteins due to its presence in amino acids like methionine and cysteine.
  • Used extensively in the vulcanization process of rubber, where sulfur cross-links polymer chains to enhance durability and elasticity.
  • Playing important roles in various biological processes within living organisms, including metabolic pathways involving sulfur-containing compounds.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 16
Number of shells: 3
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁴.

elements.Name: Chlorine
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by Carl Wilhelm Scheele in 1774, produced by reacting manganese dioxide (MnO₂) with hydrochloric acid (HCl); named chlorine by Sir Humphry Davy in 1810 from the Greek chloros, meaning pale green.

Physical Properties:

Chlorine is a yellow-green gas at room temperature with a strong, pungent odor. It is highly toxic and denser than air. Chlorine has a melting point of approximately -101°C and boils at -34°C.

Chemical Properties:

  • A strong oxidizing agent due to its tendency to readily accept electrons to complete its outer shell.
  • Forms both ionic and covalent bonds with other elements, often resulting in chlorides or organic chlorinated compounds.
  • Widely used in water treatment processes for disinfection purposes due to its ability to kill bacteria and other pathogens.
  • Playing an important role in many industrial processes, including bleaching textiles and manufacturing plastics like PVC (polyvinyl chloride).
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 17
Number of shells: 3
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁵.

elements.Name: Argon
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by Lord Rayleigh and William Ramsay in 1894 in air; named argon by H.G. Madan, derived from the Greek argos, meaning inactive.

Physical Properties:

Argon is a colorless, odorless gas that makes up approximately 0.934% of Earth's atmosphere, making it the third most abundant gas after nitrogen and oxygen. It has a low boiling point of -185.85°C and is heavier than air.

Chemical Properties:

  • A chemically inert element due to its full outer energy level, which makes it non-reactive under normal conditions.
  • Widely used in lighting applications such as incandescent bulbs and fluorescent tubes due to its ability to maintain an electric discharge without reacting with other elements.
  • Importantly used in welding processes as an inert shielding gas to protect molten metal from atmospheric gases that could cause oxidation or contamination.
  • Does not form natural compounds with other elements sbecause of its stable electronic configuration.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 18
Number of shells: 3
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶.

elements.Name: Potassium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by Sir Humphry Davy in 1807 through electrolysis; named potassium by Davy the same year from the English pot ash (kalium in Latin).

Physical Properties:

Potassium is a soft, silvery-white metal that reacts highly with water, producing hydrogen gas and releasing heat. It has a low melting point of approximately 63.38°C and serves as an excellent conductor of electricity due to its free electrons.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms strong ionic bonds due to its tendency to readily lose one electron, creating positively charged ions (K⁺).
  • An essential component for nerve function in biological systems, helping transmit signals across neurons.
  • Importantly used in maintaining soil fertility because it supports plant growth by facilitating nutrient uptake.
  • A key element in living cells due to its role in maintaining fluid balance and supporting various cellular processes.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 19
Number of shells: 4
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 4s¹.

elements.Name: Calcium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by Sir Humphry Davy in 1808 through electrolysis; named calcium by Davy the same year from the Latin calx, meaning lime.

Physical Properties:

Calcium is a soft, silvery-white metal that reacts with water to produce hydrogen gas and calcium hydroxide. It is essential for forming bones and teeth in biological systems and is the fifth most abundant element in Earth's crust. Calcium has a melting point of approximately 842°C and boils at about 1484°C[1][5].

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms strong ionic bonds due to its tendency to readily lose two electrons, creating positively charged ions (Ca²⁺).
  • Playing a crucial role in bone structure by providing rigidity and support through its incorporation into hydroxyapatite.
  • Widely used in construction materials like cement due to its ability to form stable compounds with other elements.
  • Essential for muscle function as it helps regulate muscle contraction and relaxation processes within living organisms.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 20
Number of shells: 4
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 4s².

elements.Name: Scandium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Scandium was discovered in 1879 by Swedish chemist Lars Fredrik Nilson while analyzing the minerals euxenite and gadolinite. He isolated scandium oxide (Sc₂O₃) from these minerals. The name “Scandium” comes from Scandia, the Latin word for Scandinavia, where the mineral was first found. Its discovery helped confirm Dmitri Mendeleev’s predictions about a missing element he had called eka-boron.

Physical Properties:

Scandium is a soft, silvery-white metal that is lightweight but strong. It has a high melting point (1541°C) and is relatively rare in nature.

Chemical Properties:

  • Reacts slowly with air, forming a yellowish or pink oxide layer.
  • Reacts with water and most dilute acids, forming hydrogen gas.
  • Forms trivalent ions (Sc³⁺) in compounds.
  • Used in aluminum-scandium alloys for aerospace and sports equipment.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 21
Number of shells: 4
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹ 4s².

elements.Name: Titanium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Titanium was first discovered in 1791 by British mineralogist William Gregor in a mineral called ilmenite. A few years later, German chemist Martin Heinrich Klaproth independently rediscovered the element in the mineral rutile and named it “Titanium,” after the Titans of Greek mythology — the powerful deities. This name reflects the metal’s strength and durability.

Physical Properties:

Titanium is a strong, lustrous, and corrosion-resistant metal with a silver-gray color. It is lightweight and has a high melting point of 1668°C, making it ideal for high-performance applications.

Chemical Properties:

  • Highly resistant to corrosion, even in seawater and chlorine.
  • Forms a stable oxide layer (TiO₂) that protects it from further oxidation.
  • Reacts with oxygen at high temperatures to form titanium dioxide.
  • Forms compounds typically in the +4 oxidation state.
  • Used in aerospace, medical implants, and white pigments.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 22
Number of shells: 4
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d² 4s².

elements.Name: Vanadium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Vanadium was first discovered in 1801 by Spanish-Mexican scientist Andrés Manuel del Río, who identified it in a mineral he called brown lead. However, his findings were overlooked. In 1830, Swedish chemist Nils Gabriel Sefström rediscovered the element and named it Vanadium after Vanadis, another name for the Norse goddess Freyja, because of the beautiful colors of its compounds.

Physical Properties:

Vanadium is a hard, silvery-gray metal that is ductile and corrosion-resistant. It has a high melting point of 1910°C and is moderately dense.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms compounds in multiple oxidation states (+2 to +5), with +5 being the most stable.
  • Known for colorful compounds, especially vanadates.
  • Resistant to corrosion by alkalis and acids.
  • Used in making high-strength steel alloys and catalysts.
  • Forms vanadium pentoxide (V₂O₅), useful in sulfuric acid production.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 23
Number of shells: 4
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d³ 4s².

elements.Name: Chromium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Chromium was discovered in 1797 by French chemist Louis-Nicolas Vauquelin. He isolated it from the mineral crocoite (lead chromate). The name comes from the Greek word chroma, meaning “color,” because its compounds display a wide range of vibrant colors.

Physical Properties:

Chromium is a hard, shiny, steel-gray metal with a high melting point of 1907°C. It is highly polished and does not tarnish easily, making it ideal for coatings.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms a passive oxide layer (Cr₂O₃) that protects it from corrosion.
  • Common oxidation states are +3 and +6.
  • Hexavalent chromium compounds are strong oxidizing agents.
  • Used in chrome plating, dyes, and stainless steel production.
  • Resistant to tarnishing and most acids.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 24
Number of shells: 4
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d⁵ 4s¹.

elements.Name: Manganese
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Manganese was recognized as an element in 1774 by Swedish chemist Johan Gottlieb Gahn, who isolated it from the mineral pyrolusite (MnO₂). The name comes from the Latin word magnes, which referred to both magnetite and pyrolusite due to their magnetic properties.

Physical Properties:

Manganese is a gray-white, hard, brittle metal. It is not magnetic and has a melting point of 1246°C. It easily oxidizes in air.

Chemical Properties:

  • Exhibits multiple oxidation states, especially +2, +4, and +7.
  • Forms colorful compounds (e.g., pink Mn²⁺, purple MnO₄⁻).
  • Reacts with oxygen to form manganese dioxide (MnO₂).
  • Used in steelmaking to remove oxygen and sulfur.
  • Acts as a catalyst in photosynthesis (biological role).
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 25
Number of shells: 4
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d⁵ 4s².

elements.Name: Iron
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Iron has been known since ancient times and was used by early civilizations over 5000 years ago. The symbol Fe comes from the Latin word ferrum. It played a major role in human history, especially during the Iron Age.

Physical Properties:

Iron is a dense, silvery-gray metal that is malleable and magnetic. It has a melting point of 1538°C and is abundant in Earth’s crust.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation states: +2 (ferrous) and +3 (ferric).
  • Reacts with oxygen and moisture to form rust (Fe₂O₃·xH₂O).
  • Forms iron oxides and sulfides.
  • Used in the production of steel and construction materials.
  • Acts as a key element in hemoglobin (biological role).
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 26
Number of shells: 4
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d⁶ 4s².

elements.Name: Cobalt
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Cobalt was isolated in 1735 by Swedish chemist Georg Brandt, who proved that a blue pigment used in glass came from a new element, not bismuth. The name “cobalt” comes from the German word Kobold, meaning goblin, because miners believed the ore was cursed—yielding poisonous fumes and no useful metals.

Physical Properties:

Cobalt is a hard, lustrous, bluish-gray metal. It is magnetic and has a melting point of 1495°C. It maintains its strength at high temperatures.

Chemical Properties:

  • Shows oxidation states of +2 and +3.
  • Reacts slowly with air and acids.
  • Forms bright blue compounds (e.g., cobalt(II) chloride).
  • Used in alloys, magnets, and rechargeable batteries.
  • Essential trace element in vitamin B₁₂.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 27
Number of shells: 4
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d⁷ 4s².

elements.Name: Nickel
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Nickel was first isolated in 1751 by Swedish chemist Axel Fredrik Cronstedt. He extracted it from the mineral niccolite (now called nickeline). The name comes from the German word kupfernickel, meaning devil’s copper or false copper, because miners often mistook it for copper but found it useless and blamed goblins.

Physical Properties:

Nickel is a hard, silvery-white metal with a shiny surface. It is ductile, malleable, and resistant to corrosion. It has a melting point of 1455°C and is magnetic at room temperature.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation state is +2; +3 is less common.
  • Reacts slowly with air, forming a thin oxide layer.
  • Resistant to corrosion by alkalis and acids.
  • Used in stainless steel, coins, and rechargeable batteries.
  • Acts as a catalyst in hydrogenation reactions.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 28
Number of shells: 4
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d⁸ 4s².

elements.Name: Copper
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Copper has been used by humans for over 10,000 years and was one of the first metals to be extracted and used. The symbol Cu comes from the Latin word cuprum, derived from Cyprus, the island where it was mined in ancient times.

Physical Properties:

Copper is a soft, reddish-brown metal known for its excellent electrical and thermal conductivity. It is ductile, malleable, and has a melting point of 1085°C.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms +1 and +2 oxidation states.
  • Reacts with moist air to form a green patina (copper carbonate).
  • Easily reacts with acids like nitric acid.
  • Used in electrical wiring, plumbing, and coins.
  • Forms colorful compounds (e.g., blue copper(II) sulfate).
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 29
Number of shells: 4
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s¹.

elements.Name: Zinc
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Zinc was recognized as a distinct element in India as early as the 9th century, but it was isolated in Europe by German chemist Andreas Marggraf in 1746. The name “zinc” likely comes from the German word zinke, meaning pointed or sharp, referring to the sharp spikes formed when zinc metal condenses.

Physical Properties:

Zinc is a bluish-silver, moderately reactive metal. It is brittle at room temperature but becomes malleable when heated. It has a melting point of 419.5°C.

Chemical Properties:

  • Exhibits a +2 oxidation state in most compounds.
  • Reacts with acids to release hydrogen gas.
  • Forms protective zinc oxide (ZnO) layer when exposed to air.
  • Used for galvanizing iron to prevent rusting.
  • Reacts with strong bases to form zincates.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 30
Number of shells: 4
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s².

elements.Name: Gallium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Gallium was discovered in 1875 by French chemist Paul-Émile Lecoq de Boisbaudran using spectroscopy. He named the element Gallia, Latin for France. Interestingly, his own name “Lecoq” also translates to rooster (gallus in Latin), making the name a subtle nod to both himself and his country.

Physical Properties:

Gallium is a soft, silvery metal that melts just above room temperature (29.76°C). It is denser in liquid form and expands upon solidification.

Chemical Properties:

  • Usually forms +3 oxidation states in compounds.
  • Reacts slowly with air and acids.
  • Forms gallium oxide (Ga₂O₃) on exposure to air.
  • Dissolves in both acids and alkalis (amphoteric).
  • Used in semiconductors and LEDs.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 31
Number of shells: 4
Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p¹.

elements.Name: Germanium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Germanium was discovered in 1886 by German chemist Clemens Winkler while analyzing the mineral argyrodite. He named it in honor of his homeland, Germany (Germania in Latin). The discovery confirmed Mendeleev’s prediction of “eka-silicon.”

Physical Properties:

Germanium is a lustrous, hard, grayish-white metalloid. It is brittle and has semiconductor properties.

Chemical Properties:

  • Exhibits +2 and +4 oxidation states.
  • Forms oxides like GeO₂ and GeO.
  • Reacts with oxygen when heated.
  • Poor conductor at room temperature, but better at higher temperatures (semiconductor).
  • Used in fiber optics, transistors, and infrared optics.

elements.Name: Arsenic
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Arsenic has been known since ancient times, likely in mineral forms like orpiment (As₂S₃). The name comes from the Greek word arsenikon, meaning yellow orpiment, which later became arsenicum in Latin.

Physical Properties:

Arsenic exists in multiple allotropes, most commonly as a brittle, gray metalloid. It sublimates (turns to gas) at 613°C and has poor conductivity.

Chemical Properties:

  • Shows +3 and +5 oxidation states.
  • Toxic and forms poisonous compounds like As₂O₃.
  • Combines with metals to form arsenides.
  • Used in pesticides, semiconductors, and alloys.
  • Reacts with halogens and oxidizing agents.

elements.Name: Selenium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Selenium was discovered in 1817 by Swedish chemist Jöns Jakob Berzelius, who found it in a residue from sulfuric acid production. He named it after the Greek word selene, meaning “moon,” due to its resemblance to tellurium, which was named after the Earth.

Physical Properties:

Selenium can appear as a red powder or gray metallic form. It is brittle, and the gray allotrope conducts electricity when exposed to light (photoconductivity).

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation states: -2, +4, +6.
  • Forms selenides with metals.
  • Combines with oxygen to form SeO₂.
  • Toxic in large doses but essential in small amounts.
  • Used in photocopiers, solar cells, and glassmaking.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Bromine
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Bromine was discovered in 1826 by French chemist Antoine Balard. The name comes from the Greek word bromos, meaning “stench,” due to its strong, unpleasant smell.

Physical Properties:

Bromine is a reddish-brown liquid at room temperature and is the only non-metal that is a liquid under normal conditions. It evaporates easily and has a strong odor.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation states: -1, +1, +3, +5.
  • Strong oxidizing agent.
  • Reacts with metals to form bromides.
  • Used in flame retardants, pesticides, and water treatment.
  • Corrosive and toxic in high concentrations.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Krypton
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Krypton was discovered in 1898 by British chemists Sir William Ramsay and Morris Travers while studying liquefied air. The name comes from the Greek kryptos, meaning “hidden,” as it was difficult to isolate.

Physical Properties:

Krypton is a colorless, odorless, and tasteless gas. It is inert and glows with a pale white-violet light in electric fields.

Chemical Properties:

  • Extremely unreactive under normal conditions.
  • Can form compounds with fluorine under special conditions (e.g., KrF₂).
  • Used in high-performance lighting and photography flashes.
  • Rare in Earth’s atmosphere.
  • Non-toxic but asphyxiating in high concentrations.

elements.Name: Rubidium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1861 by German chemists Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff using flame spectroscopy. The name comes from the Latin rubidus, meaning “deep red,” due to its bright red spectral lines.

Physical Properties:

Rubidium is a soft, silvery metal that is highly reactive. It melts at 39.3°C and can catch fire in air or water.

Chemical Properties:

  • Very reactive, especially with water.
  • Forms strong bases (e.g., RbOH).
  • Stored in oil to prevent air/water reactions.
  • Used in atomic clocks and research.
  • Burns with a reddish-violet flame.

elements.Name: Strontium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Strontium was discovered in 1790 by Adair Crawford in a Scottish mineral called strontianite. It was named after the village of Strontian in Scotland.

Physical Properties:

Strontium is a soft, silvery-yellow metal. It is reactive and turns yellowish when exposed to air. It melts at 777°C.

Chemical Properties:

  • Reacts quickly with water to form Sr(OH)₂.
  • Combines with oxygen and halogens easily.
  • Burns with a bright red flame (used in fireworks).
  • Forms Sr²⁺ in most compounds.
  • Stored under oil due to high reactivity.

elements.Name: Yttrium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Yttrium was discovered in 1794 by Finnish chemist Johan Gadolin. It was named after the village of Ytterby in Sweden, where the mineral gadolinite was found.

Physical Properties:

Yttrium is a silvery-metallic, ductile metal that is stable in air due to oxide formation. It melts at 1526°C.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms Y³⁺ ions in compounds.
  • Reacts slowly with water and air.
  • Used in LEDs, lasers, and superconductors.
  • Forms yttrium oxide (Y₂O₃), used in ceramics.
  • Important in cancer treatment (radioisotopes).

elements.Name: Zirconium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Zirconium was discovered in 1789 by German chemist Martin Heinrich Klaproth in the mineral zircon. The name comes from the Persian word zargun, meaning “gold-colored.”

Physical Properties:

Zirconium is a strong, corrosion-resistant, grayish-white metal. It has a high melting point (1855°C) and is used in nuclear reactors due to its low neutron absorption.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms Zr⁴⁺ ions in compounds.
  • Highly resistant to corrosion.
  • Forms zirconium dioxide (ZrO₂), a heat-resistant ceramic.
  • Reacts with halogens and acids.
  • Used in surgical instruments and reactors.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Niobium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1801 by Charles Hatchett in a mineral called columbite. It was initially named columbium, after Columbia (a poetic name for the US), but was later renamed niobium to match Greek mythology (Niobe, daughter of Tantalus). The name reflects its chemical similarity to tantalum.

Physical Properties:

Niobium is a soft, gray, ductile metal with a high melting point (2477°C). It resists corrosion and maintains strength at high temperatures.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation state is +5.
  • Forms stable oxides like Nb₂O₅.
  • Resistant to acids but reacts with hot concentrated ones.
  • Used in superconductors and stainless steel alloys.
  • Combines with halogens at high temperatures.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Molybdenum
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1778 by Carl Wilhelm Scheele and isolated in 1781 by Peter Jacob Hjelm. The name comes from the Greek molybdos, meaning lead, because molybdenite (MoS₂) was once mistaken for a lead ore.

Physical Properties:

Molybdenum is a hard, silvery metal with a very high melting point (2623°C). It is dense and resists wear and corrosion.

Chemical Properties:

  • Oxidation states range from +2 to +6; +6 is most stable.
  • Forms molybdenum trioxide (MoO₃).
  • Resistant to dilute acids.
  • Used in steel alloys and lubricants.
  • Essential trace element in enzymes.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Technetium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Technetium was the first element to be artificially produced, discovered by Carlo Perrier and Emilio Segrè in 1937. Its name comes from the Greek technetos, meaning “artificial.”

Physical Properties:

It is a silvery-gray metal, radioactive, and resembles platinum. It’s rarely found in nature.

Chemical Properties:

  • Exhibits oxidation states from +1 to +7.
  • Most stable isotope: Tc-99.
  • Used in nuclear medicine for imaging.
  • Reacts with oxygen to form Tc₂O₇.
  • Combines with halogens and acids.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Ruthenium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1844 by Russian chemist Karl Klaus while analyzing platinum ores. He named it after Ruthenia, the Latin word for Russia.

Physical Properties:

Ruthenium is a hard, brittle, gray-white metal with a high melting point (2334°C). It is corrosion-resistant.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation states: +2, +3, +4, +6, +8.
  • Forms oxides and halides.
  • Used in electrical contacts and catalysts.
  • Stable in air, resists acids.
  • Used in solar cells and fountain pen nibs.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d⁷ 5s¹.

elements.Name: Rhodium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by William Hyde Wollaston in 1803 from platinum ore. The name comes from the Greek rhodon, meaning “rose,” because of the rose-colored salts it forms.

Physical Properties:

Rhodium is a silvery-white, reflective, corrosion-resistant metal. It has a high melting point (1964°C) and is extremely rare.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation states: +1, +3.
  • Forms rhodium(III) chloride and other salts.
  • Stable in air and resistant to acids.
  • Used in catalytic converters and jewelry.
  • Highly inert and non-reactive.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Palladium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1803 by William Hyde Wollaston. Named after the asteroid Pallas, which itself was named for the Greek goddess of wisdom.

Physical Properties:

Palladium is a soft, silvery-white metal. It is ductile and absorbs hydrogen gas readily. It has a melting point of 1554.9°C.

Chemical Properties:

  • Oxidation states: 0, +2, +4.
  • Reacts with hydrogen and halogens.
  • Forms complexes and alloys.
  • Used in fuel cells, electronics, and catalytic converters.
  • Excellent hydrogen storage capability.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Silver
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Used since antiquity. The symbol Ag comes from the Latin argentum, from Greek argyros, meaning shining. It has been known for at least 5000 years.

Physical Properties:

Silver is a soft, white, lustrous metal with the highest electrical and thermal conductivity of all elements. Melting point: 961.8°C.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms Ag⁺ in most compounds.
  • Tarnishes in air due to silver sulfide formation.
  • Reacts with nitric acid but not with hydrochloric acid.
  • Used in mirrors, jewelry, electronics.
  • Forms compounds like silver nitrate (AgNO₃).
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Cadmium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1817 by Friedrich Stromeyer in zinc carbonate ores. Named after cadmia, the Latin name for calamine (zinc ore).

Physical Properties:

Cadmium is a soft, bluish-white metal. It melts at 321°C and is toxic in large amounts.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation state is +2.
  • Reacts with acids to produce hydrogen.
  • Forms cadmium oxide (CdO) and sulfide (CdS).
  • Used in batteries, pigments, coatings.
  • Toxic; environmental pollutant.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Indium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1863 by Ferdinand Reich and Hieronymous Richter via spectroscopy. Named for the indigo-blue spectral line observed.

Physical Properties:

Indium is a soft, silvery-white metal. It is malleable and melts at 156.6°C. It leaves a mark when pressed.

Chemical Properties:

  • Oxidation states: +1, +3.
  • Forms indium oxide (In₂O₃).
  • Reacts with halogens and acids.
  • Used in touchscreens and solar panels.
  • Soft and low-melting alloy material.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 49

Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p¹.

elements.Name: Tin
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Known since ancient times and used by civilizations such as the Egyptians and Romans. The name “tin” is of Anglo-Saxon origin, while the symbol Sn comes from the Latin word stannum, meaning tin.

Physical Properties:

Soft, silvery-white metal with a low melting point of 231.9°C. Malleable and corrosion-resistant. It exists in two main allotropes: grey tin (brittle) below 13.2°C and white tin (metallic) above this temperature.

Chemical Properties:

  • Exhibits +2 and +4 oxidation states in its compounds.
  • Forms tin(II) oxide (SnO) and tin(IV) oxide (SnO₂) when it reacts with oxygen.
  • Reacts with acids like HCl, releasing hydrogen and forming tin salts.
  • Combines with halogens (like chlorine and iodine) to form tin halides (e.g., SnCl₂, SnI₄).
  • Resistant to corrosion, which makes it ideal for coating other metals (e.g., tin-plated steel).

elements.Name: Antimony
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Known since ancient times, mentioned in Egyptian papyri. The name comes from Latin antimonium (possibly from Arabic al-uthmānī) and the symbol Sb from the Latin stibium, meaning “mark” (used in cosmetics like kohl).

Physical Properties:

Silvery, brittle metalloid with a melting point of 630.6°C. It conducts electricity poorly and expands on solidifying.

Chemical Properties:

  • Exhibits +3 and +5 oxidation states in compounds.
  • Forms antimony trioxide (Sb₂O₃) when it reacts with oxygen in air.
  • Combines with halogens (like chlorine and bromine) to form antimony halides (e.g., SbCl₃, SbBr₅).
  • Dissolves in concentrated acids, forming antimony salts and releasing gases.
  • Moderately reactive with air when heated, producing oxides and emitting white fumes.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Tellurium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1782 by Franz-Joseph Müller von Reichenstein. Named after the Latin word tellus, meaning earth.

Physical Properties:

Tellurium is a brittle, silvery-white metalloid with metallic luster. It has a melting point of 449.5°C and is semiconducting.

Chemical Properties:

  • Exhibits oxidation states of –2, +2, +4, and +6 in various compounds.
  • Forms tellurium dioxide (TeO₂) when it reacts with oxygen.
  • Reacts with halogens (like fluorine and chlorine) to form tellurium halides.
  • Dissolves in strong acids, forming tellurium salts and releasing gases.
  • Used in thermoelectric devices, solar panels, and alloys due to its semiconducting properties.
  • Toxic in high concentrations, especially in compound form.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Iodine
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1811 by Bernard Courtois. The name comes from the Greek ioeides, meaning violet-colored, referring to its vapor.

Physical Properties:

Dark-gray solid with a shiny luster that sublimates to form violet gas. Melting point: 113.7°C.

Chemical Properties:

  • Commonly forms the iodide ion (I⁻) in ionic compounds.
  • Reacts with metals to form metal iodides (e.g., NaI, KI).
  • Reacts with nonmetals like hydrogen to form hydrogen iodide (HI).
  • Exists as diatomic iodine (I₂) in elemental form; also forms compounds like iodine monochloride (ICl).
  • Moderately reactive; dissolves in water to form weak iodine-based acids, like hydroiodic acid (HI).
  • Used in antiseptics, nutritional supplements (iodized salt), and dyes.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

Electronic configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁵.

elements.Name: Xenon
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1898 by William Ramsay and Morris Travers. The name comes from Greek xenos, meaning stranger or foreign.

Physical Properties:

Colorless, odorless noble gas. Denser than air and condenses at –108°C.

Chemical Properties:

  • Generally chemically inert, like other noble gases.
  • Forms compounds under specific conditions, such as xenon difluoride (XeF₂) and xenon tetrafluoride (XeF₄).
  • Reacts with strong oxidizing or fluorinating agents under high pressure or electric discharge.
  • Shows oxidation states ranging from 0 (elemental) to +2, +4, +6, and +8 in compounds.
  • Used in high-intensity lamps, anesthesia, and ion propulsion systems.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Cesium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1860 by Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff using flame spectroscopy. Named after the Latin caesius, meaning sky blue, referring to its spectral lines.

Physical Properties:

Soft, silvery-gold metal. Melts at 28.5°C (liquid near room temp). Highly reactive and low-density.

Chemical Properties:

  • Extremely reactive with water and air, forming cesium hydroxide (CsOH) and releasing hydrogen gas.
  • Always forms the Cs⁺ ion in compounds (oxidation state +1).
  • Burns with a characteristic violet or blue flame when ignited.
  • Used in atomic clocks, photoelectric cells, and vacuum tubes due to its precise electron emission.
  • Stored under mineral oil or inert gas to prevent rapid oxidation and violent reactions.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Barium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1808 by Humphry Davy. Named from Greek barys, meaning “heavy,” due to high density of its compounds.

Physical Properties:

Soft, silvery-white metal. Melting point: 727°C. High density and reactive.

Chemical Properties:

  • Reacts vigorously with water, forming barium hydroxide (Ba(OH)₂) and hydrogen gas.
  • Combines with oxygen in air to form barium oxide (BaO).
  • Forms the Ba²⁺ ion in most of its compounds (oxidation state +2).
  • Used in fireworks to produce a green flame and in medical imaging as barium sulfate (BaSO₄).
  • Soluble barium compounds are toxic and must be handled with care.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 56

Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 6s².

elements.Name: Lanthanides
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1839 by Carl Gustav Mosander. The name comes from Greek lanthanein, meaning “to lie hidden,” since it was hidden in cerium ore.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-white, soft metal. Melting point: 920°C. Tarnishes quickly in air.

Chemical Properties:

  • Reacts with water, forming lanthanum hydroxide (La(OH)₃) and hydrogen gas.
  • Combines with oxygen in air to form lanthanum oxide (La₂O₃).
  • Forms the La³⁺ ion, its most stable oxidation state.
  • Reacts with halogens and acids, forming halides (e.g., LaCl₃) and salts.
  • Chemically active and marks the beginning of the lanthanide series.

elements.Name: Lanthanum
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1839 by Carl Gustav Mosander. The name comes from Greek lanthanein, meaning “to lie hidden,” since it was hidden in cerium ore.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-white, soft metal. Melting point: 920°C. Tarnishes quickly in air.

Chemical Properties:

  • Reacts with water, forming lanthanum hydroxide (La(OH)₃) and hydrogen gas.
  • Combines with oxygen in air to form lanthanum oxide (La₂O₃).
  • Forms the La³⁺ ion, its most stable oxidation state.
  • Reacts with halogens and acids, forming halides (e.g., LaCl₃) and salts.
  • Chemically active and marks the beginning of the lanthanide series.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Cerium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered independently in 1803 by Berzelius, Hisinger, and Klaproth. Named after the dwarf planet Ceres.

Physical Properties:

Silvery, malleable, soft metal. Melting point: 798°C. Oxidizes in air.

Chemical Properties:

  • Exhibits +3 and +4 oxidation states, with Ce⁴⁺ found in strong oxidizing compounds.
  • Reacts with water, acids, and halogens, forming cerium salts and halides.
  • Forms cerium oxide (CeO₂), a strong oxidizer used in catalysts and glass polishing.
  • Absorbs hydrogen easily, forming metal hydrides.
  • Chemically active, especially in finely divided form.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Praseodymium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Isolated in 1885 by Carl Auer von Welsbach. The name means “green twin” from Greek prasios (green) and didymos (twin), referring to its green salts and origin in didymium.

Physical Properties:

Soft, silvery metal. Melting point: 931°C. Tarnishes in air.

Chemical Properties:

  • Commonly forms the Pr³⁺ ion, its most stable oxidation state.
  • Reacts slowly with water, forming praseodymium hydroxide (Pr(OH)₃) and hydrogen gas.
  • Combines with halogens to form halides like PrCl₃.
  • Dissolves in acids, producing praseodymium salts.
  • Used in glass coloring, magnets, and high-strength alloys.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 59

Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f³ 6s².

elements.Name: Neodymium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1885 by Carl Auer von Welsbach during the separation of didymium. Name comes from Greek neos didymos, meaning “new twin.”

Physical Properties:

Silvery metal, slightly magnetic. Melting point: 1024°C. Tarnishes in air.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms the Nd³⁺ ion in most compounds (oxidation state +3).
  • Reacts with air, forming a protective oxide layer (Nd₂O₃).
  • Reacts with water slowly, producing neodymium hydroxide (Nd(OH)₃).
  • Combines with halogens and acids, forming halides like NdCl₃ and various salts.
  • Used in powerful magnets (NdFeB) and laser materials due to its electronic structure.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

Number of shells: 6

elements.Name: Promethium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1945 by Jacob A. Marinsky, Lawrence Glendenin, and Charles D. Coryell at Oak Ridge National Lab. Named after Prometheus, the Greek Titan who stole fire from the gods—symbolizing nuclear power.

Physical Properties:

Soft, metallic, and radioactive. Glows faintly in the dark due to its radioactivity. Melting point: ~1042°C.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms the Pm³⁺ ion, which is its most stable and common oxidation state.
  • Reacts with oxygen, forming promethium oxide (Pm₂O₃).
  • Reacts with water and acids, producing Pm(OH)₃ and releasing hydrogen gas.
  • Combines with halogens to form halides like PmCl₃.
  • Radioactive element, used in nuclear batteries and luminous paints.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 61
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f⁵ 6s².

elements.Name: Samarium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1879 by Paul Émile Lecoq de Boisbaudran. Named after the mineral samarskite, which was named after Russian engineer Colonel Samarsky.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-white metal, relatively stable in dry air. Melting point: 1072°C. Moderately hard.

Chemical Properties:

  • Commonly forms Sm³⁺ ion, though Sm²⁺ can also occur in some compounds.
  • Reacts slowly with cold water and more rapidly with hot water, forming samarium hydroxide (Sm(OH)₃).
  • Burns in air to form samarium oxide (Sm₂O₃).
  • Reacts with acids and halogens, forming salts and halides like SmCl₃.
  • Used in magnets (SmCo₅), neutron absorbers, and specialized glasses.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

elements.Name: Europium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1901 by Eugène-Anatole Demarçay. Named after the continent Europe.

Physical Properties:

Soft, ductile, silvery metal. Melts at 822°C. Reacts quickly with air and water.

Chemical Properties:

  • Exhibits +2 and +3 oxidation states, with Eu²⁺ being relatively stable compared to most lanthanides.
  • Reacts quickly with water, forming europium hydroxide (Eu(OH)₃) and hydrogen gas.
  • Burns in air, forming europium oxide (Eu₂O₃).
  • Reacts with acids and halogens, producing halides like EuCl₃.
  • Used in phosphors for TVs and fluorescent lamps due to its red and blue emissions.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f⁷ 6s².

elements.Name: Gadolinium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1880 by Jean Charles Galissard de Marignac. Named after the mineral gadolinite, which honored Finnish chemist Johan Gadolin.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-white, malleable metal. Melting point: 1312°C. Magnetic at room temperature.

Chemical Properties:

  • Usually forms the Gd³⁺ ion, its most stable oxidation state.
  • Reacts slowly with cold water, more rapidly with hot water, forming gadolinium hydroxide (Gd(OH)₃).
  • Burns in air, forming gadolinium oxide (Gd₂O₃).
  • Combines with acids and halogens, forming salts like GdCl₃.
  • Used in MRI contrast agents, alloys, and neutron shielding materials.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

Number of shells: 6

elements.Name: Terbium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1843 by Carl Gustaf Mosander. Named after the village of Ytterby in Sweden, where the ore was found.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-gray metal, soft and ductile. Melting point: 1356°C. Stable in air at room temp.

Chemical Properties:

  • Primarily forms the Tb³⁺ ion, but Tb⁴⁺ compounds also exist (e.g., TbO₂).
  • Reacts slowly with water, forming terbium hydroxide (Tb(OH)₃) and releasing hydrogen gas.
  • Combines with oxygen, forming terbium oxide (Tb₄O₇), a mixed-valence oxide.
  • Reacts with acids and halogens, forming salts like TbCl₃.
  • Used in green phosphors, solid-state devices, and magneto-optic materials.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 65
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f⁹ 6s².

elements.Name: Dysprosium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1886 by Paul Émile Lecoq de Boisbaudran. From Greek dysprositos, meaning “hard to get,” referring to difficulty in isolation.

Physical Properties:

Silvery metal, soft and dense. Melting point: 1412°C. High magnetic susceptibility.

Chemical Properties:

  • Typically forms Dy³⁺ ion, its most stable oxidation state.
  • Reacts slowly with cold water, faster with hot water, forming dysprosium hydroxide (Dy(OH)₃).
  • Burns in air, producing dysprosium oxide (Dy₂O₃).
  • Reacts with acids and halogens, forming compounds like DyCl₃.
  • Used in magnets, control rods in nuclear reactors, and laser materials.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 66
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁰ 6s².

elements.Name: Holmium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1878 by Per Theodor Cleve. Named after Stockholm (Latin: Holmia), Sweden.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-white, soft, and ductile. Melting point: 1472°C. Strongest known magnetic moment.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms the Ho³⁺ ion as its stable oxidation state.
  • Reacts slowly with water, forming holmium hydroxide (Ho(OH)₃).
  • Combines with oxygen, forming holmium oxide (Ho₂O₃), a pale yellow compound.
  • Reacts with acids and halogens, producing salts like HoCl₃.
  • Used in magnets, solid-state lasers, and nuclear control rods.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:

Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹¹ 6s².

elements.Name: Erbium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1843 by Carl Gustaf Mosander. Named after the Swedish village Ytterby.

Physical Properties:

Soft, malleable silvery metal. Melts at 1529°C. Pink-colored salts.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms the Er³⁺ ion, which is its most stable oxidation state.
  • Reacts slowly with cold water, forming erbium hydroxide (Er(OH)₃).
  • Burns in air, producing erbium oxide (Er₂O₃), which is pink.
  • Reacts with acids and halogens, forming compounds such as ErCl₃.
  • Used in fiber-optic communication, lasers, and nuclear technology.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 68
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹² 6s².

elements.Name: Thulium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1879 by Per Theodor Cleve. Named after Thule, an ancient name for Scandinavia.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-gray metal, soft and ductile. Melting point: 1545°C. Emits blue-green light.

Chemical Properties:

  • Commonly forms the Tm³⁺ ion, which is stable in compounds.
  • Reacts slowly with water, forming thulium hydroxide (Tm(OH)₃).
  • Combines with oxygen, producing thulium oxide (Tm₂O₃), a greenish compound.
  • Reacts with acids and halogens, forming salts like TmCl₃.
  • Used in portable X-ray devices and lasers due to its efficient emission properties.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 69
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹³ 6s².

elements.Name: Ytterbium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1878 by Jean Charles Galissard de Marignac. Named after Ytterby, Sweden.

Physical Properties:

Soft, silvery, and shiny metal. Melts at 824°C. Very reactive and volatile.

Chemical Properties:

  • Usually forms the Yb³⁺ ion, but the Yb²⁺ ion is also stable in some compounds.
  • Reacts slowly with water, forming ytterbium hydroxide (Yb(OH)₃) and hydrogen gas.
  • Burns in air, producing ytterbium oxide (Yb₂O₃), a white solid.
  • Reacts readily with acids, forming salts like YbCl₃.
  • Used in lasers, atomic clocks, and stainless steel alloys.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 70
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 6s².

elements.Name: Lutetium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered independently in 1907 by Georges Urbain, Carl Auer von Welsbach, and Charles James. Named after Lutetia, the ancient Roman name for Paris.

Physical Properties:

Dense, silvery-white metal. Melting point: 1663°C. Hardest and heaviest lanthanide.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms the Lu³⁺ ion, which is the only common oxidation state.
  • Reacts slowly with water, forming lutetium hydroxide (Lu(OH)₃).
  • Burns in air, producing lutetium oxide (Lu₂O₃), a white compound.
  • Reacts with acids and halogens, forming salts such as LuCl₃.
  • Used in PET scan detectors, catalysts, and research applications.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 71
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹ 6s².

elements.Name: Hafnium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1923 by Dirk Coster and George de Hevesy. Named after Hafnia, the Latin name for Copenhagen.

Physical Properties:

Silvery, lustrous, ductile metal. Melting point: 2233°C. Corrosion-resistant and dense.

Chemical Properties:

  • Oxidation state: +4 is the most stable and common.
  • Forms hafnium dioxide (HfO₂), which is highly resistant to heat and corrosion.
  • Reacts with halogens (e.g., F₂, Cl₂) and dilute acids, forming compounds like HfCl₄.
  • Used in nuclear reactor control rods, gas turbines, and superalloys.
  • Chemically very similar to zirconium, making separation difficult.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 72
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d² 6s².

elements.Name: Tantalum
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1802 by Anders Ekeberg. Named after Tantalus, a Greek mythological figure, because it “tantalizingly” resists absorbing acid.

Physical Properties:

Hard, blue-gray, very dense metal. Melting point: 3017°C. High corrosion resistance.

Chemical Properties:

  • Most stable oxidation state is +5 in its compounds.
  • Forms tantalum pentoxide (Ta₂O₅), used in capacitors and glass coatings.
  • Highly resistant to corrosion by acids, including aqua regia.
  • Reacts with halogens (e.g., forms TaCl₅) at high temperatures.
  • Used in electronics, surgical implants, and chemical equipment due to its inertness.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 73
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d³ 6s².

elements.Name: Tungsten
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1783 by the Elhuyar brothers. From Swedish tung sten, meaning “heavy stone.” Symbol W is from Wolfram, its German name.

Physical Properties:

Gray-white metal, extremely dense. Highest melting point of all metals: 3422°C.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation states: +6, +5, +4, and +2.
  • Forms tungsten(VI) oxide (WO₃), which is used in electrochromic devices.
  • Resistant to most acids, but dissolves in strong oxidizing acids like nitric acid.
  • Forms stable carbides (e.g., WC) used in cutting tools and abrasives.
  • Used in light bulb filaments, electrodes, and high-temperature alloys.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 74
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d⁴ 6s².

elements.Name: Rhenium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1925 by Ida Noddack, Walter Noddack, and Otto Berg. Named after the Rhine River (Latin: Rhenus).

Physical Properties:

Dense, silver-gray metal. Melting point: 3186°C. Third-highest melting point.

Chemical Properties:

  • Exhibits multiple oxidation states, commonly +7, +6, +4, and +2.
  • Forms rhenium(VII) oxide (Re₂O₇), a volatile and acidic compound.
  • Resistant to corrosion and stable in air at room temperature.
  • Reacts with halogens and acids, forming compounds like ReCl₅ and HReO₄.
  • Used in superalloys, catalysts (e.g., in reforming gasoline), and thermocouples.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 75
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d⁵ 6s².

elements.Name: Osmium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1803 by Smithson Tennant. Named from Greek osme, meaning “smell,” due to its pungent oxide.

Physical Properties:

Bluish-white, extremely dense (densest element). Melting point: 3033°C. Brittle in pure form.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation states: +4, +6, and +8 (highest of any element).
  • Forms osmium tetroxide (OsO₄), a toxic, volatile, and highly oxidizing compound.
  • Resistant to acids and corrosion; dissolves in molten alkalis or oxidizing agents.
  • Combines with halogens and forms coordination complexes.
  • Used in fountain pen tips, electrical contacts, and microscopy stains.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 76
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d⁶ 6s².

elements.Name: Iridium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1803 by Smithson Tennant. Named after the Greek goddess Iris, due to its colorful salts.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-white, brittle metal. Melting point: 2446°C. One of the most corrosion-resistant elements.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation states: +3 and +4 (also +6 in rare compounds).
  • Forms iridium dioxide (IrO₂) and other stable oxides.
  • Highly resistant to corrosion—one of the most inert metals.
  • Reacts with halogens at high temperatures (e.g., forms IrF₆).
  • Used in spark plugs, crucibles, and deep-sea communication equipment.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 77
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d⁷ 6s².

elements.Name: Platinum
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Known to South Americans before Europeans. Named from Spanish platina, meaning “little silver.”

Physical Properties:

Silvery-white, malleable, and dense. Melting point: 1768°C. Very unreactive.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation states: +2 and +4 (also forms +1 and +6 in some compounds).
  • Forms compounds like platinum(IV) chloride (PtCl₄) and platinum(II) complexes.
  • Inert to most acids, but dissolves in aqua regia (mixture of HCl and HNO₃).
  • Forms stable coordination compounds used in catalysis and chemotherapy (e.g., cisplatin).
  • Widely used as a catalyst, in jewelry, and in vehicle emission control systems.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 78
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d⁹ 6s¹.

elements.Name: Gold
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Known since prehistoric times. Symbol Au is from Latin aurum, meaning “shining dawn.”

Physical Properties:

Soft, yellow metal. Melting point: 1064°C. Ductile and malleable.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation states: +1 (aurous) and +3 (auric).
  • Forms compounds like gold(I) chloride (AuCl) and gold(III) chloride (AuCl₃).
  • Highly unreactive; does not tarnish in air or water.
  • Dissolves only in aqua regia, forming chloroauric acid (HAuCl₄).
  • Used in electronics, dentistry, and as a catalyst in organic reactions.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 79
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s¹.

elements.Name: Mercury
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Known since ancient times. Symbol Hg from Latin hydrargyrum, meaning “liquid silver.”

Physical Properties:

Only metal that is liquid at room temperature. Melting point: -38.83°C. Shiny, silvery appearance.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation states: +1 (mercurous) and +2 (mercuric).
  • Forms compounds like mercuric chloride (HgCl₂) and mercurous nitrate (Hg₂(NO₃)₂).
  • Reacts with sulfur, halogens, and concentrated nitric or sulfuric acid.
  • Forms amalgams (alloys) with many metals, including gold and silver.
  • Toxic and volatile; used in thermometers, barometers, and fluorescent lamps (phasing out due to toxicity).
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 80
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s².

elements.Name: Thallium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1861 by William Crookes using flame spectroscopy. Named from Greek thallos, meaning “green shoot,” due to its green spectral emission.

Physical Properties:

Soft, bluish-white metal. Melting point: 304°C. Easily cut with a knife and tarnishes in air.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation states: +1 (more stable) and +3.
  • Forms thallium(I) sulfate (Tl₂SO₄) and thallium(III) oxide (Tl₂O₃).
  • Reacts with acids, halogens, and oxygen.
  • Highly toxic; used in limited applications like electronics and optical systems.
  • Resembles alkali metals in +1 state behavior.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 81
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p¹.

elements.Name: Lead
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Known since ancient times; used by Romans for pipes and containers. Symbol Pb is from Latin plumbum, meaning “lead.”

Physical Properties:

Soft, dense, bluish-gray metal. Melting point: 327.5°C. Malleable but tarnishes on exposure to air.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation states: +2 (stable) and +4.
  • Forms lead(II) oxide (PbO) and lead(IV) oxide (PbO₂).
  • Reacts with acids, especially nitric acid, and forms salts.
  • Used in batteries, radiation shielding, and old plumbing.
  • Toxic, especially in soluble and dust forms.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 82
