Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p².

elements.Name: Bismuth
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Known since ancient times; often confused with lead or tin. The name comes from the German word Wismut, meaning white mass.

Physical Properties:

Brittle, silvery-pink metal with a shiny surface. Melting point: 271.4°C. Expands when solidifying and has low thermal conductivity.

Chemical Properties:

  • Shows a stable +3 oxidation state.
  • Forms compounds like bismuth(III) oxide (Bi₂O₃).
  • Reacts slowly with oxygen and acids.
  • Used in cosmetics, medicines (e.g., bismuth subsalicylate), and alloys.
  • Considered one of the least toxic heavy metals.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 83
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p³.

elements.Name: Polonium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1898 by Marie and Pierre Curie. Named after Marie Curie’s native country, Poland (Latin: Polonia), as a tribute and to highlight its political struggles.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-gray, metallic-looking solid. Highly radioactive and glows faintly due to energy release. Melting point: 254°C. Conducts electricity poorly.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms stable +2 and +4 oxidation states.
  • Reacts with oxygen to form polonium dioxide (PoO₂).
  • Reacts slowly with dilute acids.
  • Combines with halogens to form PoCl₂ and PoCl₄.
  • Extremely toxic and radioactive—handled in sealed environments.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 84
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁴.

elements.Name: Astatine
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1940 by Dale R. Corson, Kenneth Ross MacKenzie, and Emilio Segrè. The name comes from the Greek word astatos, meaning unstable, referring to its radioactive nature.

Physical Properties:

Very rare, radioactive element. Likely a dark, metallic-looking solid. Estimated melting point: 302°C. Exists in extremely small amounts in nature.

Chemical Properties:

  • Usually shows –1, +1, +3, +5, and +7 oxidation states.
  • Forms hydrogen astatide (HAt) when combined with hydrogen.
  • Reacts with metals to form astatides (e.g., NaAt).
  • Can form interhalogen compounds like AtI and AtBr.
  • Least reactive halogen but chemically similar to iodine.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 85
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁵.

elements.Name: Radon
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1900 by Friedrich Ernst Dorn. The name is derived from radium as it was first observed as a decay product of radium.

Physical Properties:

Colorless, odorless radioactive noble gas. Becomes a liquid below –61.8°C and a solid below –71°C. Heavier than air and dense.

Chemical Properties:

  • Chemically inert but can form compounds like radon fluoride (RnF₂) under extreme conditions.
  • Exhibits oxidation state of +2 in rare compounds.
  • Radioactive and decays to form solid polonium.
  • Used in radiation therapy but limited due to radioactivity.
  • Inhalation hazard—can accumulate in buildings and increase cancer risk.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 86
Number of shells: 6
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶.

elements.Name: Francium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1939 by Marguerite Perey at the Curie Institute in Paris. Named after France, her home country.

Physical Properties:

Extremely rare and radioactive. Estimated melting point around 27°C. Soft, metallic appearance (based on predictions). Short half-life and exists only in trace amounts.

Chemical Properties:

  • Highly reactive alkali metal—most reactive of its group.
  • Forms Fr⁺ ion and reacts explosively with water.
  • Reacts with halogens to form salts like francium chloride (FrCl).
  • Strongly electropositive; behaves like cesium but more intensely.
  • Radioactive decay limits practical use—mostly studied in labs.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 87
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 7s¹.

elements.Name: Radium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1898 by Marie and Pierre Curie from uranium ore (pitchblende). Named from Latin radius, meaning ray, due to its intense radioactivity.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-white metal that glows faintly in the dark due to radioactivity. Melting point: ~700°C. Denser than barium and extremely radioactive.

Chemical Properties:

  • Reacts with water to form radium hydroxide (Ra(OH)₂).
  • Forms Ra²⁺ ion in compounds.
  • Reacts with halogens to form salts (e.g., RaCl₂).
  • Very similar to barium in reactivity but more intense due to radioactivity.
  • Emits alpha particles; compounds are highly radioactive and toxic.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 88
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 7s².

elements.Name: Actinides
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1899 by Friedrich Oskar Giesel. The name comes from the Greek word aktinos, meaning ray or beam, referring to its radioactive emissions.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-white, soft, and radioactive metal. Glows blue in the dark due to intense radioactivity. Melting point: ~1050°C. Chemically similar to lanthanum.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms Ac³⁺ ion in most compounds.
  • Reacts with oxygen to form actinium oxide (Ac₂O₃).
  • Combines with halogens to form halides (e.g., AcCl₃).
  • Reacts with acids to release hydrogen gas.
  • Highly radioactive and used in neutron sources and cancer therapy research.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 89
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 6d¹ 7s².

elements.Name: Actinium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1899 by Friedrich Oskar Giesel. The name comes from the Greek word aktinos, meaning ray or beam, referring to its radioactive emissions.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-white, soft, and radioactive metal. Glows blue in the dark due to intense radioactivity. Melting point: ~1050°C. Chemically similar to lanthanum.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms Ac³⁺ ion in most compounds.
  • Reacts with oxygen to form actinium oxide (Ac₂O₃).
  • Combines with halogens to form halides (e.g., AcCl₃).
  • Reacts with acids to release hydrogen gas.
  • Highly radioactive and used in neutron sources and cancer therapy research.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 89
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 6d¹ 7s².

elements.Name: Thorium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1828 by Jöns Jakob Berzelius. Named after Thor, the Norse god of thunder, reflecting its powerful radioactive nature.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-white, soft, and radioactive metal. Melting point: 1750°C. Tarnishes slowly in air and becomes dull gray or black.

Chemical Properties:

  • Commonly shows a +4 oxidation state (Th⁴⁺).
  • Forms thorium dioxide (ThO₂), which is highly stable.
  • Reacts with halogens to form halides like ThCl₄.
  • Slowly reacts with water and more rapidly with acids.
  • Used in gas mantles, nuclear fuels, and research on molten salt reactors.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 90
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 6d² 7s².

elements.Name: Protactinium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1913 by Kasimir Fajans and Oswald Helm. The name comes from Greek protos (first) and actinium, meaning parent of actinium because it decays to actinium.

Physical Properties:

Dense, silvery metal with a melting point of 1572°C. Radioactive and slowly tarnishes in air.

Chemical Properties:

  • Usually shows a +5 oxidation state.
  • Slowly reacts with air and moisture, forming a dull coating.
  • Can combine with halogens (like chlorine) to form stable compounds.
  • Very reactive in fine powder form.
  • Used mainly in scientific research due to scarcity and radioactivity.
  • Very reactive with oxygen and moisture when finely divided.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 91
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f² 6d¹ 7s².

elements.Name: Uranium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1789 by Martin Heinrich Klaproth. Named after the planet Uranus, which had been discovered just a few years earlier.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-gray metal, radioactive. Melting point: 1135°C. Dense and malleable.

Chemical Properties:

  • Shows +3, +4, +5, and +6 oxidation states.
  • Reacts with oxygen to form uranium oxides.
  • Dissolves in acids, forming uranium salts.
  • Used as fuel in nuclear reactors and weapons.
  • Can form colored salts and is highly radioactive.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 92
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f³ 6d¹ 7s².

elements.Name: Neptunium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1940 by Edwin McMillan and Philip Abelson. Named after the planet Neptune, following Uranium.

Physical Properties:

Silvery, radioactive metal. Melting point: 639°C. Tarnishes in air and forms a green oxide layer.

Chemical Properties:

  • Shows multiple oxidation states: +3 to +7 (most stable is +5).
  • Reacts with oxygen, acids, and halogens to form various compounds.
  • Slowly oxidizes in air, forming a green coating.
  • Chemically behaves like uranium and plutonium.
  • Used in nuclear research and reactor targets.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 93
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f⁴ 6d¹ 7s².

elements.Name: Plutonium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1940 by Glenn Seaborg and his team. Named after Pluto, the next planet after Neptune.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-gray metal, radioactive. Melting point: 640°C. Changes structure with temperature and oxidizes in air.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation states: +3, +4, +5, +6.
  • Reacts easily with air, water vapor, and acids.
  • Forms oxides and halides depending on the environment.
  • Powdered plutonium can ignite in air.
  • Very reactive when finely divided.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 94
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f⁶ 7s².

elements.Name: Americium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Americium was discovered in 1944 by Glenn T. Seaborg and his team at the University of California, Berkeley, during nuclear experiments involving plutonium in a reactor. The element was first produced by bombarding plutonium-239 with neutrons. It was named Americium after the continent America, to parallel the naming of Europium, another element named after Europe.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-white, soft, radioactive metal. Melting point: 1176°C.

Chemical Properties:

  • Most common oxidation state: +3.
  • Reacts with oxygen and acids to produce salts.
  • Forms stable oxides and halides.
  • Used in smoke detectors and research.
  • Emits alpha particles and requires careful handling.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 95
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f⁷ 7s².

elements.Name: Curium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Curium was discovered in 1944 by Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, and Albert Ghiorso at the University of California, Berkeley. It was produced by bombarding plutonium with alpha particles. The element was named Curium in honor of Marie and Pierre Curie, the pioneering scientists known for their groundbreaking research on radioactivity.

Physical Properties:

Silvery, dense, radioactive metal. Melting point: 1340°C. Glows in the dark due to intense radioactivity.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation state: +3.
  • Forms compounds like CmO₂ and CmCl₃.
  • Reacts with acids and halogens.
  • Used in space probes as a heat source.
  • Highly radioactive and produces heat.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 96
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f⁷ 6d¹ 7s².

elements.Name: Berkelium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1949 at the University of California, Berkeley. Named after the city of Berkeley.

Physical Properties:

Radioactive metal with silvery appearance. Melting point: ~986°C.

Chemical Properties:

  • Typically found in the +3 oxidation state.
  • Combines with oxygen, acids, and halogens.
  • Forms compounds like BkO₂ and BkCl₃.
  • Chemically similar to curium and actinium.
  • Used mainly in scientific research due to rarity.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 97
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f⁹ 7s².

elements.Name: Californium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1950 by Stanley Thompson, Kenneth Street Jr., Albert Ghiorso, and Glenn T. Seaborg at the University of California, Berkeley. Named after the state and university of California where it was synthesized by bombarding curium-242 with alpha particles.

Physical Properties:

Silvery-white metal. Radioactive and only available in very small amounts. Melting point: ~900°C. Soft and malleable, but its physical form is rarely seen due to high radioactivity.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation state: +3 (Cf³⁺), which is most stable in aqueous solutions.
  • Forms compounds like californium oxide (Cf₂O₃) and californium chloride (CfCl₃).
  • Reacts with oxygen and moist air to form a dull oxide layer.
  • Can form water-soluble salts; used in neutron moisture gauges and nuclear reactors.
  • Highly radioactive and requires careful handling due to its intense neutron emission.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 98
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁰ 7s².

elements.Name: Einsteinium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1952 by Albert Ghiorso and his team while analyzing debris from the first hydrogen bomb explosion. Named in honor of Albert Einstein for his contributions to physics.

Physical Properties:

Silvery, radioactive metal. Soft and malleable. Difficult to study due to its short half-life and intense radioactivity.

Chemical Properties:

  • Most stable oxidation state is +3 (forms Es³⁺ compounds).
  • Forms compounds like einsteinium oxide (Es₂O₃) and chloride (EsCl₃).
  • Reacts slowly with oxygen and acids.
  • Chemistry resembles other late actinides like californium.
  • Highly radioactive; handled only in specialized facilities.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 99
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹¹ 7s².

elements.Name: Fermium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1952 by Albert Ghiorso and team while analyzing debris from the first hydrogen bomb test (Ivy Mike) in the Pacific. Named after physicist Enrico Fermi for his pioneering work in nuclear physics.

Physical Properties:

Fermium is a synthetic, radioactive metal with no bulk sample available. Likely a silvery-white metal with metallic luster. Estimated melting point: ~1527°C.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation state is +3; +2 appears in some compounds.
  • Forms compounds like fermium(III) chloride and fermium(III) nitrate.
  • Reactivity studied only in tracer amounts due to limited availability.
  • Shows chemical similarities to other late actinides like einsteinium.
  • Extremely radioactive and unstable; decays by alpha emission.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 100
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹² 7s².

elements.Name: Mendelevium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

First synthesized in 1955 by a team including Albert Ghiorso, Glenn Seaborg, and Bernard Harvey by bombarding einsteinium with alpha particles. Named in honor of Dmitri Mendeleev, creator of the periodic table.

Physical Properties:

Synthetic and highly radioactive. Likely a dense, silvery metal. Only produced in trace amounts; not enough for direct visual observation.

Chemical Properties:

  • Exhibits mainly the +3 oxidation state; +2 observed in special cases.
  • Forms stable trivalent ions like Md³⁺ in aqueous solution.
  • Reacts with halogens and acids in trace experiments.
  • Similar behavior to californium and einsteinium.
  • Strong alpha emitter; unstable with short half-lives.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 101
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹³ 7s².

elements.Name: Nobelium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

First identified in 1958 by scientists at the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research in Dubna, Russia. Named after Alfred Nobel, inventor of dynamite and founder of the Nobel Prizes.

Physical Properties:

Radioactive synthetic metal. Thought to be silvery and metallic. Produced in microgram amounts, preventing bulk property studies.

Chemical Properties:

  • Most stable in +2 oxidation state, unlike other actinides.
  • Forms compounds like nobelium(II) chloride and nitrate.
  • Shows chemical behavior similar to alkaline earth metals due to its +2 state.
  • Highly unstable and short-lived.
  • Studied using ion exchange and chromatography methods.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 102
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 7s².

elements.Name: Lawrencium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1961 by Albert Ghiorso and team at UC Berkeley. Named after Ernest O. Lawrence, inventor of the cyclotron.

Physical Properties:

Synthetic and radioactive. Likely a silvery-white metal. Exists only in trace amounts, so physical appearance is inferred.

Chemical Properties:

  • Exhibits a +3 oxidation state in compounds.
  • Forms stable trivalent ions, similar to lutetium and actinium.
  • Can form chlorides and other halide salts.
  • Less chemically reactive than earlier actinides.
  • Highly unstable with rapid radioactive decay.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 103
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 7s² 7p¹.

elements.Name: Rutherfordium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered independently in 1964 at Dubna and in 1969 at Berkeley. Naming controversy resolved in favor of Rutherfordium, honoring Ernest Rutherford, the father of nuclear physics.

Physical Properties:

Presumed to be a dense, silvery metal. Exists only in atom-scale amounts. Solid at room temperature.

Chemical Properties:

  • Forms +4 oxidation state in most compounds.
  • Behaves chemically like hafnium and zirconium.
  • Forms oxides and chlorides in trace reactions.
  • Studied using gas-phase chemistry and chromatography.
  • Extremely short-lived isotopes limit extensive study.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 104
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 6d² 7s².

elements.Name: Dubnium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Claimed by both JINR (1967) and Berkeley (1970); named Dubnium in 1997 after the Russian research center Dubna, acknowledging the disputed discovery.

Physical Properties:

Synthetic and highly radioactive. Likely metallic and solid. Exists only in a few atoms at a time.

Chemical Properties:

  • +5 is the most stable oxidation state.
  • Shows chemical similarity to niobium and tantalum.
  • Forms pentahalides and oxychlorides.
  • Studied using gas-phase and aqueous chemistry.
  • Extremely unstable; decays quickly via alpha emission.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 105
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 6d³ 7s².

elements.Name: Seaborgium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1974 by the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory team. Named after Glenn T. Seaborg, an American chemist who contributed to the discovery of many transuranium elements.

Physical Properties:

Short-lived radioactive metal. Believed to be solid with metallic properties. Not visually observed due to limited production.

Chemical Properties:

  • Common oxidation state is +6, similar to tungsten.
  • Forms volatile oxychloride compounds like SgO₂Cl₂.
  • Chemically behaves like molybdenum and tungsten.
  • Studied using rapid chemical separation methods.
  • All isotopes are unstable and decay quickly.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 106
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 6d⁴ 7s².

elements.Name: Bohrium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1981 by scientists at GSI in Germany. Named in honor of Niels Bohr, Danish physicist known for atomic structure theory.

Physical Properties:

Expected to be a heavy, silvery metal. Solid at room temperature. Extremely short half-life prevents bulk study.

Chemical Properties:

  • Likely forms +7 oxidation state, like rhenium.
  • Forms oxyhalide and oxo compounds in gas-phase studies.
  • Behavior resembles that of group 7 elements (Re, Tc).
  • Studied using fast radiochemical techniques.
  • Extremely radioactive and short-lived.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 107
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 6d⁵ 7s².

elements.Name: Hassium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1984 at GSI Darmstadt by a German research team. Named after the German state of Hesse (Latin: Hassia), where the institute is located.

Physical Properties:

Highly radioactive synthetic metal. Thought to be dense and silvery. Only observed atom by atom.

Chemical Properties:

  • Oxidation state +8 is predicted, like osmium.
  • Forms volatile tetroxides (HsO₄) in gas-phase experiments.
  • Behaves like a heavier analog of osmium.
  • Studied using advanced radiochemical separation.
  • Very unstable with extremely short half-lives.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 108
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 6d⁶ 7s².

elements.Name: Meitnerium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Synthesized in 1982 at GSI Darmstadt by bombarding bismuth with iron nuclei. Named in honor of Lise Meitner, a pioneer in nuclear physics and co-discoverer of nuclear fission.

Physical Properties:

Extremely radioactive and short-lived; only a few atoms have been produced. Physical appearance is unknown, but predicted to be metallic and dense.

Chemical Properties:

  • Predicted to show behavior similar to iridium (group 9).
  • May form +3 and +1 oxidation states, with +3 likely most stable.
  • Expected to be unreactive to air due to short half-life.
  • Chemical behavior is mostly theoretical due to limited production.
  • Used only in scientific research.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 109
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 6d⁷ 7s².

elements.Name: Darmstadtium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1994 at GSI in Darmstadt, Germany, by bombarding lead with nickel ions. Named after the city of Darmstadt, home to the research institute.

Physical Properties:

Extremely unstable; no bulk sample exists. Likely a dense, silvery-white metal if it were stable.

Chemical Properties:

  • Belongs to group 10; may behave like platinum or palladium.
  • Oxidation state +2 or +4 is predicted to be stable.
  • Too short-lived to observe reactions directly.
  • Not reactive under normal conditions due to rapid decay.
  • No commercial uses; studied for nuclear properties only.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 110
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 6d⁸ 7s².

elements.Name: Roentgenium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 1994 at GSI, Germany. Named in honor of Wilhelm Röntgen, discoverer of X-rays.

Physical Properties:

Possibly a solid metal, predicted to have a silvery or metallic appearance. Exists only in trace amounts due to short half-life.

Chemical Properties:

  • Predicted to resemble gold or silver chemically.
  • May exhibit +1 and +3 oxidation states.
  • Extremely short-lived, limiting experimental data.
  • Inert under most conditions due to instability.
  • Studied in atomic structure and relativistic chemistry.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 111
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 6d⁹ 7s².

elements.Name: Copernicium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

First produced in 1996 at GSI, Germany, by colliding zinc and lead nuclei. Named after astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus.

Physical Properties:

Predicted to be a volatile, dense, and possibly gaseous metal. May have properties similar to mercury or be more inert.

Chemical Properties:

  • May form a +2 oxidation state, like mercury.
  • High volatility predicted; may behave like a noble gas under some conditions.
  • Reactivity extremely low due to strong relativistic effects.
  • Experimental studies suggest inert or noble-metal-like behavior.
  • Unstable and radioactive; used in scientific studies only.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 112
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 6d¹⁰ 7s².

elements.Name: Nihonium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered by Japanese scientists at RIKEN in 2004 and confirmed in 2012. Named Nihonium from Nihon, meaning Japan, honoring its place of discovery.

Physical Properties:

Unknown, likely a solid metal. Predicted to be soft and metallic, possibly silver-white.

Chemical Properties:

  • Expected to form +1 and +3 oxidation states.
  • May resemble thallium or indium in chemical behavior.
  • Extremely short-lived and unstable.
  • Reactivity expected to be low due to relativistic effects.
  • Studied only at the atomic level.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 113
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 6d¹⁰ 7s² 7p¹.

elements.Name: Flerovium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

First synthesized in 1998 by the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research in Dubna, Russia, in collaboration with Lawrence Livermore National Lab. Named after the Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions.

Physical Properties:

Possibly a very heavy metal with low melting point. Some predictions suggest it may be a gas under normal conditions.

Chemical Properties:

  • Predicted to show weak metallic or noble gas-like properties.
  • May form +2 or +4 oxidation states.
  • Expected to be relatively unreactive.
  • No bulk samples; chemical behavior studied through single-atom experiments.
  • High interest in its relativistic effects and stability.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 114
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 6d¹⁰ 7s² 7p².

elements.Name: Moscovium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered jointly by Russian and American scientists in 2003. Named after Moscow Oblast, home to the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research.

Physical Properties:

Very heavy and unstable. Likely a metallic solid, but appearance is unknown due to short lifespan.

Chemical Properties:

  • Expected to behave like bismuth or arsenic.
  • Likely oxidation states: +1 and +3.
  • Chemical studies are theoretical or limited to atom-scale experiments.
  • Reactivity unknown; may be low due to strong nuclear effects.
  • Studied only in nuclear physics.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 115
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 6d¹⁰ 7s² 7p³.

elements.Name: Livermorium
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Discovered in 2000 by a team from Dubna, Russia, and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in the USA. Named to honor Livermore, California.

Physical Properties:

Predicted to be a dense metal. No visual data available due to rapid decay.

Chemical Properties:

  • Similar to polonium in group 16.
  • Likely oxidation states: –2, +2, possibly +4.
  • Predicted to have moderate reactivity.
  • Studied through theoretical modeling and single-atom experiments.
  • No practical applications; purely research-based.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 116
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 6d¹⁰ 7s² 7p⁴.

elements.Name: Tennessine
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

Synthesized in 2010 by an international collaboration between Russian, American, and Oak Ridge National Laboratory scientists. Named after Tennessee, recognizing the role of its research institutions.

Physical Properties:

Likely a solid at room temperature. May resemble astatine but with even lower reactivity.

Chemical Properties:

  • Expected to have halogen-like traits, though much less reactive.
  • Oxidation states: –1, +1, +3, possibly +5.
  • Reactivity lower than iodine or astatine due to relativistic effects.
  • Predicted to form halide-type compounds.
  • Chemically studied at single-atom level.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 117
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 6d¹⁰ 7s² 7p⁵.

elements.Name: Oganesson
elements.Description:
Discovery & Word Origin:

First synthesized in 2002 by scientists at Dubna and Lawrence Livermore. Named in honor of Russian physicist Yuri Oganessian for his extensive work on superheavy elements.

Physical Properties:

Expected to be a solid or possibly a metallic noble gas. May have high polarizability and weak bonding.

Chemical Properties:

  • Least reactive of noble gases but may form bonds under special conditions.
  • Predicted oxidation state: 0, possibly +2.
  • High atomic mass and electron shielding affect its reactivity.
  • May form compounds like OgF₂ theoretically.
  • Under study for understanding stability in superheavy nuclei.
elements.ElectronicConfiguration:
Atomic number: 118
Number of shells: 7
Electronic configuration: 1s¹ 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁶ 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶ 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6s² 6p⁶ 5f¹⁴ 6d¹⁰ 7s² 7p⁶.
